It's not just about the blue light it emits. I'll explain how it affects your sleep. There is no research needed for this simple thing.
When we go to bed and try to sleep, there are already a lot of thoughts rushing through our brain. And after some time those thoughts naturally stop coming and slowly we fall asleep. Now suppose that we've just used our phone and now we are trying to sleep. Naturally some thoughts related to our phone will come to our mind and if we sleep with our phone just on the other side of the bed, there are high chances that we will pick it up again. We tend to do this repeatedly and we don't realize that a lot of time has already passed and in this way our sleep pattern slowly starts disrupting. I can tell this with confidence because I've experienced all of this myself. But what I do now is that I keep my phone and laptop in another room for the night so that I can have a sound sleep.

Well, from my own experience, test subject of two people, I'll say this.
I read on my phone in bed at night. Until I feel myself drifting off. My ex was the same with watching stuff on his phone.
We found that having software on like Twilight or f.lux for a tablet/computer helps with two main areas. One, you can lower the intensity of the back-light so much more (when I'm reading in pitch black, the minimum of any phones I've had is way too bright) and making the background more red, and using a "recycled paper type" of beige background on the kindle app allows me to rest my eyes. The point is to read and have a good time, not get a tension headache from squinting.

The second is, we do drift off much quicker. I can't say which proportion of it is due to the blue light balance and which is due to the fact that we're not trying to fall asleep whole holding a flashlight to our faces anymore. But yes.
